reviewText:
Originally, I had left a negative review (not recommended) due to pricing and game length issues, but after the price change and a friendly conversation with the devs, who were more than accomodating, I figured I would come back to this review in the spirit of fair play.

For those of you seeking a fun experience from a new company trying new things, this game is a nice little package.

For five euros, this game is worth the smaller investment. I honestly thoroughly enjoyed the game play. The learning curve is not steep at all, and once you master the mechanics, you'll breeze through the content. I can imagine racing your friends for the best completion time would extend the life of the game in a fun and social way as well!

Bottom line, give this company a chance, and I can see them producing high-quality content in the future.
voteText: 36 of 42 people (86%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Sneaky Sneaky plays a little like a stealth board-game.

Everything functions on very deliberate set of turns and movement speeds, constrained to a grid that acts as a means to make enemy fields of view immediately understandable. Most of Sneaky Sneaky's mechanics are fairly basic, confined to hiding in bushes and stabbing enemies in the back, but developer Naiad Entertainment manages to do a surprising amount with the few systems they have to work with. The further you progress the more involved encounters become, always consisting of only single rooms but adding in different enemy types each with a specific movement and attack pattern, and more options to use parts of the environment to hide and pick them off unawares.

Sneaky Sneaky feels a bit more like a puzzle game in this regard than a traditional stealth game. The question is usually less about how you can sneak past enemies and more along the lines of what the most efficient way to take them out would be. And it's a surprising amount of fun for how basic most of your interactions are, with the cute graphics helping a lot to make for much more lighthearted stealth affair than we're used to seeing.

Undermining this are the annoying controls, which use solely the mouse and single clicks for every action, but often demand more precision than such a simple control scheme allows. More than just making it difficult for me to quickly position my character (which is rather important when every enemy has such an exact movement speed that you need to exploit), my clicks would often not register or register too late and have me walking straight into the view of an enemy. I was constantly fighting with the controls and never confident they would do what I wanted them too, with almost every death and enemy sighting feeling the fault of a touch oriented control scheme instead of poor planning on my part.

What's so disappointing about this is it's such an easy problem to fix, whether by adding in a more appropriate keyboard or controller control scheme, or simply making the entire game turn based as happens when you're spotted. Either would almost entirely fix Sneaky Sneaky's biggest issue, and make it immensely easier to recommend, though whether either change is on the way I couldn't say. I'd be lying if I said I didn't have a lot of fun with Sneaky Sneaky, but I can only imagine how much more I'd have liked it if I hadn't been forced to play it like a mobile game.

reviewText: This game is neat. Fun idea, fun feel, fun to play... Very little depth. Not really an RPG. Had 15 levels all which took about 10-15 minutes. Just when you get a feel for the game, it's over. Beat the whole thing in 2 hours and went back to play through again. Not much replay value unfortunately. This should be a free online game, not a 5$ steam game.

reviewText:
It's a hard decision for me to say that I don't recommend this game - but in the end I believe the cons outweigh the pros.

Pros
- Fun Battle System
- Often multiple ways to complete a level
- Different ways of dealing with enemies
- Some humor throughout
- Decent Level Up System

Cons
- I beat this in 2 hours - there were only like approx. 15 levels - wayyy too short for a game of this sort - I would have loved for there to be at least double the amount of levels if not triple
- Not that many items to choose from and some aren't very helpful anyways
- Minor level interaction I.E. The only place to hide is in piles of hay or grass and only barrels, trees, rocks and jars are breakable
- Easy to screw up - I suppose if you are the patient sort this one might not be an issue but I found that quite often when I go to move my character he somehow ends up in the enemies line of sight despite my delibarite effort to keep him hidden
- Almost no story at all - plus (in my opinion) the ending is really bad
- Prices for upgrades in the store are far too expensive based on how much gold you gain per level and how few levels there are - and the upgrades aren't that helpful anyways
- Lack of variety in general - only 3 different area types that you explore through and the several levels for each area type all feel about the same
- Far too easy - Most Enemies can be easily taken out with an arrow from afar before they can react and then you can restock on arrows basically anytime you want my destroying trees or barrels - not to mention anytime you die you can hit a retry button that lets you start over from the enterance of the room you died in with no demerit
- Unneccesary score system - I suppose since the exp is linked to the score system it's kind of important but they didnt need to put one in - or at the very least - I felt no pressure to get a high score because whether you do or not you are going to get a good chunck of experience points that will almost always level you up
- Repetitive music that is the same for every level you play through

Verdict: In the end I didn't hate the 2 hours I spent playing this game but unless it is on a really good sale and you don't have any other games to play than I wouldn't recommend getting this game.

reviewText: Sneaky Sneaky is a casual and charming stealth game with rpg elements. The game isn't overly difficult, once you learn how things work you should easily get the top ranking on most stages on your first attempt. The RPG elements aren't overly deep and by the end you'll have lvled up everything. Lastly on the negatives the game is very short. I completed the game, gathered the collectables, and went back to get a gold ranking on every stage and came in at 3.3h of gameplay. So its a pretty brief experience. Aside from the negatives though i had a great time playing through the game and now that the developers have lowered the cost to $5 I'd say its certainly worth picking up for a fun night of sneaky sneaky action. Hopefully the developers will add on some more content down the road.

reviewText: Really awesome and addictive little game, similar to zelda in some ways which i really liked! Worth the money and i hope they make more

Cute, friendly, and very easy. Patience is needed for some of the timing, but other than that, anyone can play it. My munchkins loved it. Earning money is a little tedious, but play your cards right and you can do all achievements in one playthrough, without having to repeat any levels (except maybe one level to get the pacificst achievement).

Very short, enjoyable turn based / active time based stealth game.  It has a good amount of difficulty as well, although this is partly due to the controls not being as tight as they could be.\n\nDefinitely worth $5 and a couple hours of your time.

reviewText:
Sneaky Sneaky is a colorful and fun experience! You play a cute looking thief, who's after the Sultan's rubies, that are now spread everywhere across the map and 3 per level. (why is that gets clear from the opening cinematic).
The game is a mixture of turn-based combat with rpg elements and stealth action! The levels consist of a bunch of rooms connected together with one or more pathways.You can always check the map of the current level you're in by pausing the game. Once you enter a room, you notice the enemies inside (if there are any) and see their field of view. Unless you're detected by an enemy, you can freely walk around, gather stuff, trash some barrels, chop down some trees ... fun stuff. One you get detected, the game transforms into this turn based action, but with a twist - you get 3 actions per turn, or well 3 turns before the roles turn. This can be crucial, as you start the game with 3 hearts as your health pool, and if you have not upgraded that and a tough enemy spots you and deals a heart of damage per attack - you're basically rekt. So yea - staying stealthy in a stealth game is pretty important :p so hide in the bushes and behind an obstacle from enemies line of sight  . That, or you have to initiate first, so you get the first 3 turns and oneshot the enemy! The easiest way to do that, is shoot from a distance. You can't shoot from the start of the game, but you learn to use your bow fairly early, and chop down trees and barrels to convert them to arrows, as you can only carry 3 by default. That can be tricky in on itself, as barrels and trees are you main line of sight blocker, that you hide behind.
I think the game is split / themed into chapters with 5 levels each. Once you change the chapter, everything changes - the enemies, the surroundings, the music ... I'm not so far into the game - completed level 2-2, but I've seen quite a few different enemies : you have your standard guards with swords, you have a melee blob, a ranged blob, a badass wolf(I think it's a wolf) and now skeletons and snakes ... pretty good. Now you might think, that enemies move in a pattern around the rooms they are in, but that's not necessarily the case - if you chop a tree or a barrel, or eliminate an enemy - their movement pattern changes / might change, so getting the drop on them is not as simple, as you might think. Most of the time you will be waiting patiently in the bushes for them to pass by so you can oneshot them with a sneak attack, or dropping a tasty meat on the ground to get their attention, so you can calmly backstab. I mean you can probably go all Rambo, upgrade your health pool first and enter the rooms guns blazing, or well ... bow, chugging potions like an addict, but I prefer the sneaky sneaky gameplay. Important to note : when you die you can restart the level, or restart the current room you died in. If you restart the room - all enemies inside are back to life and you're with 3 hearts of life ( even if you've upgraded your total).
I think the game looks really beautiful and colorful and cute and just perfect for my taste. I find the music fitting with the overall spirit of the game ( I think the word I'm searching for is cuteness ) The controls are ... o wait, it's just the one - the control is done solely by your mouse, even the movement - maybe the game is a port from a mobile device, or made with a mobile devise in mind(the 3 stars rating system for accomplished level is a dead giveaway). I really like how you shoot the arrows, it's really thoughtful, but I do like me some keyboard controls - even if it's only for the character movement. I'm not so keen on gamepad support, but I'm sure some people will want that / point to the lack of it.
Beside the rubies, that you gather 3 per level, there are some coins / bag of dosh, that you find on each level, and that you use to buy goodies from the ingame shop - health potions, meat bait, a larger quiver and so on. Potion prices look reasonable, quiver looks a bit overpriced in my eyes, might be wrong, I'm not sure how much money you get for replaying a level, or even if you get any.
Now there is a character progression in the game - you level up and can improve 4 stats- health pool, melee damage, range damage and movement speed. I'm 7 levels into the game and I'm level 6, don't think I have replayed a level - so the progress is pretty good. Then again, now I notice, that you need level 12 to max all your skills, so I guess the game is not as lengthy as I thought! That might be an issue for some people, especially with this price tag. So in the light of recent past(Halloween) and upcoming (Xmas) sales, you might wanna wait and grab this one when cheaper, as the game is definitely worth playing.

TL:DR you can check my overview video as I show you levels 1-5 and 2-1
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=341188102
voteText: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The game is fun to play if you have a little bit of free time. However, that being said, it really takes very little time to complete this game.  That's going back to finish whatever achievments you missed while playing the title.  I finished the game in less than two days.  That includes time with it running and sitting there while I was doing other things. The graphics (Zelda comes to mind when playing this game) and sound were fine. I never encountered any of the bugs that others have. Younger gamers may like this game. It has just enough complexity for them to need to use problem solving skills, without being so long and drawn out that they lose interest. In short, the game play and looks are satisfactory for what it is, just needs more content with more complex puzzles (for older gamers) to have any kind of replay value.

reviewText: Sneaky Sneaky is a top-down stealth game where you play as a thief attempting to make it through a series of rooms without detection/dispatching your enemies and picking up treasure along the way. Enemies move in a series of periodic steps, and shifts into turn-based movement if you are detected. In addition to avoiding detection, your character gets a number of items and weapons which they can use to take care of enemies. This actually gets the game to land squarely in that narrow range in between instant lose if detected" and "too powerful so detection is meaningless" which is exceptionally rare in stealth games
date: and is the place where the best ones tend to reside.\n\nIt's rather short - I was able to 100% it in about 4 hours. However
recommended: the art style and level design lends itself to a sort of polished charm which is often lacking from games of this length.\n\nIt's a good bit of fun
hoursPlayed: and well worth the asking price of 5 bucks."

reviewText:
This game isn't bad... it's just not that great. If it was $1-2 I would say go ahead and buy it but it's just not that great.

The art is pretty nice but the gameplay itself is extremely boring and the levels are not that interesting. It plays like a flash ipad game, and if you were playing it on the ipad it would probably slightly more enjoyable.

However it still has some major design flaws in my opinion. For example when you level-up all of the abilities that you get (attack dmg up, bow dmg up, movement distance up, hearts up) are all pointless. When you kill a creature sneakily (the name of the game right?) then it's always a 1-shot kill. Thus, in my opinion the game should just drop all of the fighting stuff and just focus on the sneaking. If you get spotted, that should be it, you should get killed without any other options and then have to restart the level. Thus turning it into more of the puzzle / strategy game that it really should be. As it is now it has virtually no strategy and is extremely simple.

The only difficulty the game has is introdcued by the awkward controls, where the enemies are moving around in real-time and if you click on certain places your guy may take no action at all and thus be standing in the wrong place at the wrong time. I would much rather they converted this game into a turn-based puzzler with more interesting strategy.

reviewText:
The following review is taken in full from http://criticalindiegamer.com/2014/11/sneaky-sneaky-review-pc/


A few weeks back a little thief snuck their way onto the website, plundering rubies and capturing hearts as they went. Naiad Entertainmentâs Sneaky Sneaky left us suitably impressed when we previewed it, and now you can get your hands on it too, on Steam!

We arenât going to beat around the bush, reiterating what has already been said, but Sneaky Sneaky is a lovely little debut from Naiad. In it you play as a thief out to find the Sultanâs rubies, whilst collecting golden coins to keep your arsenal stocked up. Thereâs even some light RPG elements that allow you to level up your speed, health and the amount of damage that you deal. All of this takes place within a pretty pseudo-turn based world.

When you havenât been spotted by enemies you are free to roam around the map, collecting items and smashing up barrels. But as soon as you have been spotted the game shifts to a more traditional turn-based RPG affair. During these phases your enemies and you will each get three turns to move and fight.

Naturally, as the gameâs name suggests, you are much better off staying out of sight and striking when your enemyâs back is turned, but If you are quick enough you can land a quick backstab. But you also have a bow and arrow at your disposal. Using the bow is one of Sneaky Sneakyâs real pleasures, because it is wonderfully rewarding to use. Left clicking and pulling the mouse cursor back readies your arrow, allowing you to turn and track your opponent. Releasing the left mouse button sends your arrow hurtling towards the enemy, and land a direct hit if youâve timed things properly.

Thereâs an undeniable âearly Zeldaâ feel to the game and perhaps a visual nod here and there. Each level feels like it could have easily been in A Link To The Past â high praise indeed! Youâll visit a handful of different areas from arid deserts, leafy green forests, caves and towns looking for your rubies and the quickest way to the exit.

Each area has its own traps to avoid, or to use to your advantage. For example, certain levels contain spikes that can be activated by a switch, and crafty players could entice enemies by placing some food on the deactivated spikes, only to re-activate them when they are standing on top. And thatâs another ace up Sneaky Sneakyâs sleeve, its combat is so versatile and elastic that youâll always have multiple options at your disposal. If you want to go Rambo and take everything out by force then feel free, itâll be tougher but it is possible. The real reward, though, lays in staying out of sight and picking enemies off one by one, without being noticed. Not only does the game play best like this, youâll be rewarded much more handsomely at the end of each level. Levels come with three rankings, bronze, silver and gold, so completionists  will find a decent challenge in collecting every ruby and every gold medal, but itâs rewarding fun.

Sneaky Sneakyâs presentation is similar to many other high quality games youâve probably seen on iOS or Android; sprites are clean, nicely animated and colourful, and although the interface is undeniably lifted from the mobile version of the game, it works well and is easy to navigate .

Controls are a real breeze too and feel responsive and intuitive. Little touches like pulling the mouse back to ready your bow feel natural, and show the care and dedication that has gone into the PC version of the game.

Whether you are young or old, hardcore or casual, Sneaky Sneaky is a compelling little proposition. Itâs the perfect game to play a few levels at a time and leave running on your desktop. Kids will eat up its cartoon aesthetic whilst finding the gameplay accessible, and adults will enjoy the versatility of its combat. Pick it up on Steam, itâs a steal!
voteText: 13 of 27 people (48%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Almost a competent game, but the stealth elements are basic and the level designs are tedious, and even though the game has a nice visual aesthetic and even has good concepts, the game's controls will very often fight you by being unresponsive, which can lead to a lot of situations where stealth is blown because the game's engine seems to work on ticks, rather than in real time, so there are times where enemies will detect you in squares you aren't actually in, but have just left, or because the pathfinding is bad and you've walked into the path of an enemy, when you want to go in another direction. Most of the time spent in this game is either waiting for enemies to move into or out of position, or quitting and rejoining a map because of one of the previously mentioned problems.\n\nBasically, good ideas, bad design and execution. 4/10

reviewText:
Positives:
- Gameplay is really simple but rewarding. I also liked how the game let me discover how things work, instead of guiding me too much in the beggining.
- The music and the art are an absolute joy to watch and listen to. The entire thing looks hand-painted and is filled with funny details. The little sounds made by the enemies are funny and fit the overall theme of the game.
- The levels aren't too long, and there's no real penalty for failing. This in turn allows you to try different things quickly and to find your own way to play.
Negatives:
- Short game. Three to four hours is all you can get from the game, and that's if you want to collect all the achievements. Kind of steep for a 5â¬ game.
- The combat is turn based, except both you and your enemies get 3 turns instead of one. This felt unfair to me, especially when the enemy has the first round". Often you'll find yourself being beaten to death without even getting a chance to run or hide (which I would assume would be a good strategy in a game where the protagonist is called Sneaky).
- Whenever you destroy something in the map (be it a barrel
recommended: you then move to the cell where the thing previously was
hoursPlayed: instead of staying where you were. I have no idea why the developers insisted on this
voteText: and maybe there's even some sound logic behind it. For me
votesHelpful: as more often than not I ended up being detected by some other monster because of it.\n\nOverall
votesTotal: I'd say it was a positive experience!\n7/10

reviewText:
You ever have that game where you REALLY want to like it? Like, so much that it hurts to type a review saying you don't? That's a fair assesment of how I'm feeling currently.

I love stealth. The complexities of it, the satisfaction of sneaking by someone undetected, the rush of trying to avoid guards or enemies. Thats all fun and good. This game just feels... none of that, I guess. Its interesting, to be sure. I liked the idea, and difficulty is no stranger to the Stealth genre (is it a genre now? I'm unsure.) That said, I can't help but find myself fuming by the time I botch the timing for the 53rd time.

This game feels like it was made SPECIFICALLY for turn based gameplay, similar to the (understandably basic) battle system. It feels like it should've been that kind of game, similar to that of Invisible Inc. That said, its not. Its realtime until battle, which causes a lot of deaths, because guess what? You got the timing wrong by what was barely a pixel, and are currently getting a comfy â¥â¥â¥-shaving by the local guard.

So yeah, I honestly can't reccomend this, even to diehard stealth gamers. Maybe this is just me, and from all of the other reviews, it probably is... but this game feels unneedly difficult in realtime, with alot of cheaper detections and issues with just when you are on the tile that hides you, and when you are on the one that gets you detected.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Simple graphics suit a simple game. The controls though are not great and often end up in frustrating detection. There's a turn-based fighting system in the game, but... It's a stealth game? It's litterally called Sneaky Sneaky. Why would I want to go in a fight? Every time there's a fight, I just let myself die, as there's no other way to restart your current location (else you have to restart the entire level). The appeal of stealth games are, that they feel like action-puzzles. But there are just too many units in this game with no fixed paths, and your safest bet is to just sit in a bush and WAIT and HOPE they'll walk close enough for you to sneak-attack them, as you can't safely get up behind them, because you have no idea, whether they might just turn around and spot you. Super annoying...

reviewText:
This is a funcitonal mobile port, but also a lazy port.
First, why are there only two item slots when you can easily fit the whole row? Also, why does the game not tell you that you can move the items around? It is very frustrating to use the barrel before I found out that I can move items in the inventory. To furthur the frustration, the game is very very unresponsive: there are at least half a second delay between the mouse click and the start of the movement.
There are many inconsistencies amoung the game. For example, why does a healing potion take an action and using the barrel does not?

Conclusion:
The game is functional, but there are many better games like this one.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that this game is ridiculously fun.  It's simple, yes, but charming and addictive.  I was just getting really good at executing beautiful sneak kills...

...and then it was over.

A pitiful handful of levels makes up the entirety of the game.  I checked the map for bonus levels or secrets - nothing.  Nothing but an unsatisfying ending and a game map that fits on a single screen.

Get it on sale or else don't get it at all.  Five bucks for a collective three hours of gameplay isn't worth it.

As an introduction to the puzzle or strategy genres, I would say it's above average. True, the learning curve is fairly shallow, but the animation and play style is cute, in an off-beat Zelda kind of way. The music and minimal storyline seem to work well together as a package while not being overly distracting. You sneak, you get gems, you escape. It doesn't have to be anything beyond that.\n\nI do have a soft spot for indie titles that try to be fun in a different way, and I would say this game does just that. Pick it up for a few dollars and save it for a rainy afternoon.

Pros:
Graphics
Sound/Music
Mechanics
Fun
Price
I really liked the random paths that the AI is taking when moving mobs that are not bound to a route
Small RPG elements
You can sneak / force through most of the dungeons depending on your preference

Cons:
extremely short :-(
low replay value

Assessment - 16 puzzle dungeons probably worth your money.

Sneaky Sneaky is not a long game but it is a fun game!

The art and music are cute and good, and the puzzles are occasionally frustrating but never unfair.

My only gripe is that it's completely possible to go through the entire game (as in, find every single gem and get 'gold' on every level) and never use the sleep arrows nor get enough gold to afford the backpack upgrade, but it's better to have unnecessary extra features that don't interfere with gameplay than to leave out a cool and possibly useful idea.

I hope that a level pack or sequel or something comes out some day!
It is a lighthearted stealth game with awesome animated style graphics and fun gameplay.\nIt is a nice game to relax and enjoy. Definitely recommend this.

SHORT VERSION

Great but much too short. I'd give it a very solid nine out of ten. Can only recommend it, especially since the price has been permanently reduced.

LONG VERSION

When I made a Steam account a good friend of mine suprised me with this little gem of a game. That was many months ago and only now did I finally get around to finish everything. It has been a blast through and through and I decided to delete the save file just so I can unlock everything again during yet another playthrough somewhere down the line.

The visuals are absolutely charming, the soundtrack fits the mood perfectly, and the gameplay offers enough variation to keep things interesting. The name would make you think that you'll be doing nothing but sneaking around corners but you have the option to confront enemies up close with a dagger, take them out from afar with a bow, use the environment against them or employ items found during your journey to give you an edge.

There's a bit of RPG element to it as you level up your thief's stats and unlock new items but ultimately the game maintains its focus on the puzzle aspect. The controls are slightly clunky in a sense that you can't always predict if Sneaky moves from one tile to another just a split second before an enemy spots him or not. Leveling his speed helps but this can lend to some frustrating moments early on.

Other than that, my only complaint is the length. The game itself, if you're decent at these sort of things, can be completed in two hours. Anything after that is pure fluff - playing to increase the stats of Sneaky, to get whatever achievement you missed and to reach the highscore on each map. In my case, all of that took fifteen hours.

In closing, I would like to thank Naiad Entertainment for the experience and I hope we'll see a sequel one day. One that'll be just as charming but hopefully a bit longer. :)
Shut up and buy this game. It's worth it.\nI hope to see a sequel.

reviewText:
I have to say, I absolutely loved this game. It was brilliantly simple and very well designed. The gameplay is ULTRA tight and refined. The art style is extremely clean and pleasent and the overall game is exactly as long (or rather: as short) as it needs to be. Sneaky Sneaky doesn't overstay it's welcome. The storyline is extremely simple but at the same time, it is the essence of a more complex story. Like the rest of the game, it is only the most important elements of a story.

I've recommended quite a few games but this one in particular I would say is an essential play. Sneaky Sneaky represents what I believe to be a game that is the most well distilled, honed and perfected title I've seen since Portal 1. Sneaky Sneaky is exactly what it should have been from start to finish and there is nothing else that it needs to be.

Its worth the money. Its worth the few short hours of playtime. It's just amazingly good at what it tries to do. Check it out.
ADORABLE! This funny puzzle have only two flaws: it's short and there could be so much more puzzles and content. Though it's still good as it is. Big thumbs up!
Cons: This game is short.  (4-5 hours tops)\nPros: It's a damned good little puzzler.\n9/10 would recommend to anyone.
Fun game! Has charm and comedic playtime, but too short. Worth the buy in my book a hunred fold.

Short, funny and engaging game about adventures of a certain Thief. Puzzle game mixed with some stealth elements and simple humor. Very nice smooth and colorful graphics with decent soundtrack makes is very eye friendly. The only con is that it is really short and could have been much more. Plenty of unused potential but still worth it.

Pure fun from the beginning to the end with lovely graphics and replay value.

What I felt lacking would be an actual plot. It wouldn't have been hard to stitch a little something together to explain the anti-hero's journey.
Some sound effect could have been more pleasant, like when we crush the barrels. But I'm being picky here.
Anothiner thing is the length. As soon as I got to really master the gameplay and have the most fun I stubbled on the credit roll. If felt strange.
The abrupt ending was disappointing, but sitll not tarnishing the pleasure I had through playing. Also,

Aa far as I'm concerned, Sneaky Sneaky is worth its $5.

Sneaky Sneaky is a short but pretty game about a thief who wants to get the treasure he has stolen, back from a bird that snatched it. It is going to take you less around 4 hours to complete the game and grab all 29 achievements.

Is it certainly not the best game of the year, but it has its merits: a stealth system that works, cute graphics, good controls, and it does not require a last-gen computer to run at all. Also, if you are looking for a game that responds well to tablets, this one will do the job.

If youÂ´re looking for a short game, with simple but challenging mechanics, Sneaky Sneaky might be the game youÂ´re looking for.

LetÂ´s go for the pros first:
- The main character is funny.
- The game is simple but requires attention and patience to flawlessly clear the levels (controls are only the mouse click).
- Few but funny and useful items.
- Not very hard, actually no hard at all, except if youÂ´re going for the best results in each level, but even that is not gonna cost very much dedication. (This is actually a confusing thing to call a pro. There are those, myself included, who prefers hard games with a lot of challenge.

The cons:
- A little repetitive, but either way, the game is short.
- Some confusing detection mechanics, where the mob sees you, but donÂ´t see at all (still havenÂ´t gotten the trick on this).
- The lack of a map makes you get lost in some maps, without knowing each way you went the first time. Sum on this the repetitive screens on the levels.

I reccomend the game, itÂ´s not expensive and itÂ´s assured fun even if for just a little time.

Playable.

(I'm visually impaired, physically disabled, and my reaction times are slowed by brain damage, so knowing in advance when a game is at all playatole has value. I bet I'm not the only one.)

Sneaky Sneaky is a fun, unpretentious and unsurprising game. It is not very deep nor challenging, but it doesn't pretend to be, and is the better for it. A good game to while away some time with.
Short but a good game.
PROS:- Simple to play, fun, easy and have a few RPG elements\n\nCONS:- Really short game, about 2 or 3 hrs

I beat this game 100% in 4 hours. The whole story, upgraded the character completely, every level with full score, and unlocked all of the steam achievments. I expected more from the game, but the game was cheap enough that I got my money's worth. It was an enjoyable 4 hours, I hope they make a sequel.

Purchased on sale for 1.5â¬ and had fun, but it's super short. Lasted me an afternoon. Hope they release more levels someday. Still, I recommend it if you can get it cheap, not sure it's worth 5â¬ for 6 hours of gameplay, a lot less less time if you're a good player (I know I'm not).

I didn't expect to be challenged with Sneaky Sneaky. This game offered a surprising amount of challenge that motivated me to attain a high score in every level.

It has lite RPG elements but its core identity is of a strategy game where you sneak your way past through enemies and obstacles in the best possible way. Doing so nets you a big score which grants you higher experience points that allows you to level up your characters statistics. When you level up, more strategic options become available to you. Although I did feel that the last few levels became too easy but nevertheless, it was fun getting the game to 100% completion.

In this game, you are ultimately rewarded for being, as the title says, sneaky. Be a good ninja and pick this game up!

Nice. Funky. Sneaky.

Sneaky Sneaky is a short but pretty game about a thief who wants to get the treasure he has stolen, back from a bird that snatched it. It is going to take you less around 4 hours to complete the game and grab all 29 achievements.

Is it certainly not the best game of the year, but it has its merits: a stealth system that works, cute graphics, good controls, and it does not require a last-gen computer to run at all. Also, if you are looking for a game that responds well to tablets, this one will do the job.

I beat this game 100% in 4 hours. The whole story, upgraded the character completely, every level with full score, and unlocked all of the steam achievments. I expected more from the game, but the game was cheap enough that I got my money's worth. It was an enjoyable 4 hours, I hope they make a sequel.

TL;DR
Enjoyable but:random movement of enemies drags out the game
problems in transition between real and turn-based timeSneaky Sneaky was decently fun, but most of the short playtime was spent waiting for an opening in random enemy movement patterns. The game also lacks any real polish in its mechanics, so issues arise any time the game moves between real-time and turn-based time. For example: attack too late and your sword swing misses and the enemy detects you, move too late and enemies detect you behind a wall or outside their vision range.

Obviously it's a mobile port, so the game isn't terribly complicated. Don't expect to distract enemies with anything other than meat, and don't expect alternate routes or strategies. Some things are questionable for a mobile game as well - clicking on an empty space will move your character towards that space, but the game is not smart enough to understand that clicking on an enemy or breakable means move and attack.

Wait for a sale.

Pure fun from the beginning to the end with lovely graphics and replay value.

What I felt lacking would be an actual plot. It wouldn't have been hard to stitch a little something together to explain the anti-hero's journey.
Some sound effect could have been more pleasant, like when we crush the barrels. But I'm being picky here.
Anothiner thing is the length. As soon as I got to really master the gameplay and have the most fun I stubbled on the credit roll. If felt strange.
The abrupt ending was disappointing, but sitll not tarnishing the pleasure I had through playing. Also,

Aa far as I'm concerned, Sneaky Sneaky is worth its $5.

Short, funny and engaging game about adventures of a certain Thief. Puzzle game mixed with some stealth elements and simple humor. Very nice smooth and colorful graphics with decent soundtrack makes is very eye friendly. The only con is that it is really short and could have been much more. Plenty of unused potential but still worth it.
Good game, but very short. In the full passage and getting all the achievements it took me less than 5 hours.
Very Fun Game.... Need more levels and Boss will be great :)
A fun and yet easy little puzzle game.
this is such a cute game, lovely design and characters, and great achievments :) love at first sight
Fun little stealth game.

It's very short and simple, but that is part of the charm.  It only cost a few dollars so if you want a quick and light game for a short break, then this is a good game for you.  I also got it on sale so it was a great addition to my library.  It would also be good to play with younger kids since the concept and controls are so simple, and the art is colorful and appealing.

I really enjoy Sneaky Sneaky. It's a fun stealth puzzle game, with a few difficult levels. Some special items unlock later in the game, giving replay value to earlier levels to improve your score by getting all the gems. Lots of options for how you get through each screen, and a cheerful soundtrack, happily playing in the background. It's a great game, and well worth the price.

I have to say, I absolutely loved this game. It was brilliantly simple and very well designed. The gameplay is ULTRA tight and refined. The art style is extremely clean and pleasent and the overall game is exactly as long (or rather: as short) as it needs to be. Sneaky Sneaky doesn't overstay it's welcome. The storyline is extremely simple but at the same time, it is the essence of a more complex story. Like the rest of the game, it is only the most important elements of a story.

I've recommended quite a few games but this one in particular I would say is an essential play. Sneaky Sneaky represents what I believe to be a game that is the most well distilled, honed and perfected title I've seen since Portal 1. Sneaky Sneaky is exactly what it should have been from start to finish and there is nothing else that it needs to be.

Its worth the money. Its worth the few short hours of playtime. It's just amazingly good at what it tries to do. Check it out.
ADORABLE! This funny puzzle have only two flaws: it's short and there could be so much more puzzles and content. Though it's still good as it is. Big thumbs up!
Cute game...  Easy mechanincs.  Very polished.  Recommended to sneak freaks ONLY!  3/5
Too good to be so short. Everything about Sneaky Sneaky is fun and great, I enjoyed every level a lot and only wish there would be more to play.
It may be a short game, but it was pretty good.\n\n7/10

This is a good game with exception to of 2 problems. #1 they never bothered to debug the movement squares so what happens is sometimes when you click the square below you for no apparent reason your guy moves in another direction as if to walk around but there's nothing in the way so instead what ends up happening is he gets spotted and ends up fighting.  #2 the engagements take a painfully long time. They need to be speed up A LOT. Other then that it's a pretty good game I think.

Pros	Neat little tactical semi-turn based strategy

Cons	-Hardest part of the game is input is strictly limited to mouse and feels very cluncky and pro cause of most of your screw-ups
- Game could have offered a map restart option instead of only a full stage restart option.

This is a very clever little stealth game. Has a great balance between heat-of-the-moment reflex moments, and turn-based relaxing play. The upgrades aren't very interesting, but that hardly matters, since the variety of enemies you encounter are really what make the game evolve from beginning to end. I hope they make more like this!

I really enjoy Sneaky Sneaky. It's a fun stealth puzzle game, with a few difficult levels. Some special items unlock later in the game, giving replay value to earlier levels to improve your score by getting all the gems. Lots of options for how you get through each screen, and a cheerful soundtrack, happily playing in the background. It's a great game, and well worth the price.

Sneaky Sneaky is a very good little game.

Excellent game mechanic, but on a few rare occasions the pathing got a little crazy(2 or 3 times in the 5 hours I played).

It's a short game, but I felt that if it was any longer I might lose interest so good call devs.

Definite sale purchace. Debatable at full price. I 100%'d this in slightly over 5 hours so you're paying a dollar per hour of gameplay.
Sneaky Sneaky" is a fun
date: little puzzle game that lets you play a sneaky thief trying to escape while gathering up rubies.\n\nThe graphics are nice; nothing fancy or realistic-looking
recommended: but they work for this game.  I loved the achievements because there are none that require hundreds of hours of playing
hoursPlayed: and all of them are possible in a practical sense.  The music works well and doesn't become an ear worm after playing the game.\n\nOverall
voteText: "Sneaky Sneaky" is like the Mentos of the gaming world.  It's a great way to spend a little time before getting back to real life."

reviewText:
This was a great game to play! The stealth system is fantastic, and the signs that can be found are quite humorous. I enjoyed taking the time to play through the entire thing. Finding different ways to progress through each level and avoid obstacles to get certain achievements was pretty fun.

My only problem is that I wish it were longer! Hopefully the devs will make a sequel one day!

Oh, and I wish there were more achievements, or at least a couple more challenging ones, like ones for going through all levels without detection (at least all possible ones). It's still a great game with a few good achievements in there that make me feel acomplished at 100%ing it.

Sold on itunes for half the price... f*** you.....


Good game, but.... f*** you
